lines.text:
[to Catherine]
It's just a case of too soon old and too late smart.
[Dutchie has been seriously wounded and the nearest doctor in a hundred miles away]

Best thing you can do for him, pilgrim, is make him rest easy while he waits till the end. Anything he drinks is on the house. And then you can bury him out back and away from the hogs. And it won't cost much. I'll even carve him a nice head marker. Twenty-five dollars sound about right? The ground is kind of hard this time of year... and the diggin' ain't easy.
That's always the way, ain't it?
What's always the way?
Let a man die, right away he's "good, old Claude". How was he *before* he bucked out?
You'll be line rider up in ridge country. It pays $30 a month. You sure you rode line before?
Sure enough to have some might strong feelings about it.

I knew'd a fellow once, his wagon team got away with him and run a wheel spoke right through his middle. Bled hisself out, right there. Don't you know how easy it was? It was like taking a little sleep under a shady tree, didn't hurt none at all. He just got kind of drowsy, and he just, well, he just dozed off. Well, sir, it ain't gonna be that easy for you. No, sir, not that easy.
He dead?
No, he ain't dead. Leave him be.
Leave him? Pa . . .

Leave him be. Out here, by hisself, no goods, winter coming on. He's gonna be a long while dying. And all that time, he's gonna know who done it to him. Yes, sir, a mighty long time, and then he'll be dead.
How often do you bathe?
Well, eight or nine times. It depends.
On what?
The weather.
Eight or nine times a month?
Eight or nine times a month? A year!
A year?

Well sure. You have a real good one when you finish the shove up north, like at the hotel in Alfred. Then one or two in the winter, if you don't catch your death. Then a couple in the spring and one more good one before you start the shove up again. The rest depends on what kind of water you hit on the drive. Well, what's wrong with that? That's as much as anybody!
[Preacher forces Catherine to take up with one of his sons]
I need some time. It's a very hard choice to make.

Of course it's hard. I'll give you two days. That's fair, two days. Now, pick over all the fine points. Rafe there is smarter but he's meaner, and Rufe there, he's stronger but he's dumber. If the good Lord had seen fit to put them both together, they would have made a perfect man.
Save your money! Get you a spread of your own like me.
It wasn't money started you in the cattle business, Anse.
Well, what do you think it was, Will?
More like a long rope and a hot iron!

[Blue has just taken a shot of Catron's moonshine]
How's she taste?

[Grimacing]
Danged if I know... sure burns a dollar's worth...

[referring to the whiskey]
That stuff's for doctorin'! It's not for drinkin'!

[to Dutchy]
Hell, one job's all I need. Sharin' a blanket don't make us married.

[referring to the severely wounded Dutchy]
He's a good boy. This is no good way for him to go, Will.
Tell yuh, Blue, ain't no good way to go.
Hey, Allie, we were just trying to help him out.
Yeah, like a sharp stick in the eye.
I'm sure glad no one seen me do that. I'd be laughed off the place.
What? Milking?
No self-respectin' cowhand'd be caught dead milkin' a cow!
I won't tell anyone.
I sure won't go braggin' on it none.

[to Will]
We don't all have the same choices. We just uh don't all have the same choices.
